results.title: Public hangings. Series 2. Ep. 04
results.brief_description: Public hangings is a local television program on the arts produced for broadcast on community television (channel 31) in Melbourne, Australia from 2002. Enjoying a cult following, the program (now in its second series) produced by Irish art critic and London gallery director, Andrew MacKenzie along with co-presenter Lena Corner, roams the streets of Melbourne in search of opening nights and visual vox pops. The program’s style makes the avant garde accessible and provides an insight into a vibrant underground city culture. In this episode Melbourne City Council invites artists to respond to the recent environmental ‘Real Conference’ held in Johannassburg. Artists Louise Lavarack and Briele Hansen talk about the collaborative process specifically in regards to their project that utilises the generic plastic shopping bag. At George Paton Gallery, Sharnie Shield exhibits malleable tectohedronic forms exploring spacial possibilities of geometry. Ken Wong curates the annual Gasworks Arts Inc. artists show “Out of the Dark”. Jeff Wassman and Jamieson Miller are interviewed. Screentalk this week presents the film and projection work of artist Briele Hansen. Her work explores water in its various states (ocean, raindrops) as a metaphor for passage, transition and the human connection to the world. Excerpts are shown from works: ‘Fluid connection’ and ‘Here’.

results.title: Public hangings. Series 2. Ep. 08
results.brief_description: Public hangings is a local television program on the arts produced for broadcast on community television (channel 31) in Melbourne, Australia from 2002. Enjoying a cult following, the program (now in its second series) produced by Irish art critic and London gallery director, Andrew MacKenzie along with co-presenter Lena Corner, roams the streets of Melbourne in search of opening nights and visual vox pops. The program’s style makes the avant garde accessible and provides an insight into a vibrant underground city culture. This episode first up visits Jawbone Wetlands Nature Reserve to look at the source of inspiration of Caroline Oxley’s exhibition of paintings ‘Return To Jawbone’, exhibited at Fitzroy Gallery. Kathy Temin in ‘Kylie Night’ explores her ongoing fascination with the pop-princess-phenomenon of Kylie Minogue and the culture of identity fetishism. Collaborators Christos Linou and Robert Mangion interweave the disciplines of performance, visual arts and film making to perform and exhibit the third part of their series of work ‘The Act Of Being Inside Out’ at Mass Gallery and the County Court in Melbourne. Curated by Stuart Koop at Monash University Museum of Art is the group show ‘Gulliver’s Travels’ that seeks to explore the recent popularity of model making and the miniature in Australian art. The exhibition includes: Craige Andre, Matt Calvert, Richard Giblett, Callum Morton, Louise Paramor, Ricky Swallow and Tim Silver. Screen Talk shows an excerpt from ‘S-Crash’ by Lindsay Cox and Victor Holder.

results.title: Public hangings. Series 2. Ep. 10
results.brief_description: Public hangings is a local television program on the arts produced for broadcast on community television (channel 31) in Melbourne, Australia from 2002. Enjoying a cult following, the program (now in its second series) produced by Irish art critic and London gallery director, Andrew MacKenzie along with co-presenter Lena Corner, roams the streets of Melbourne in search of opening nights and visual vox pops. The program’s style makes the avant garde accessible and provides an insight into a vibrant underground city culture. In this episode Andrew MacKenzie interviews Juliana Enberg, director of the Australian Centre for Contemporary Art (ACCA) at the opening of it’s new building at Southbank and inaugural exhibition by Susan Norrie ‘A History of Happiness’. The American artist Steve Keene exhibits his latest work at Linden gallery with the claim as being ‘the most prolific artist in America’. His work pokes fun at the age of “mechanical” reproduction and technologically driven work. Sandra Bridie, artist in residence at Tower Studio discusses her project ‘6 Contextual Modules’ and discusses her ongoing solo practise where Bridie presents herself as a multiple of fictional artists. Dominic Lococo discusses F4, a new multi-media space. Screen Talk: Brendan Lee discusses “Projekt”, the first quarterly journal in VHS format and presents excerpts including ‘Test’ by Sanja Pahoki, ‘The Bong Relay Business’ by TV Moore and ‘Container’ by Stephen Honeggar and Anthony Hunt.

results.title: Maidens
results.brief_description: A compilation documentary of four generations of the filmmaker’s maternal family from 1906-1977 using images from old family photographs, slides, home movies and excerpts from historical Australian women’s films. The images trace the transition of the family from the extended family functioning as a productive unit on the land to the nuclear family and by the fourth generation into further disintegration and change into a yet to be defined form. Parts 1 & 11 illustrate the historical development of the image and its use by families in reading personal history. Parts 3 & 4 juxtapose fictional dramatic films in which the filmmaker appears with cinema verite and home movies thus exploring the relationship between filmic representation and reality. First Prize, General Section, Greater Union Awards, Sydney Film Festival 1978. Gold Hugo, Best Short Subject Film, Chicago Film Festival 1978.

results.title: Public hangings. Series 2. Ep. 07
results.brief_description: Public hangings is a local television program on the arts produced for broadcast on community television (channel 31) in Melbourne, Australia from 2002. Enjoying a cult following, the program (now in its second series) produced by Irish art critic and London gallery director, Andrew MacKenzie along with co-presenter Lena Corner, roams the streets of Melbourne in search of opening nights and visual vox pops. The program’s style makes the avant garde accessible and provides an insight into a vibrant underground city culture. In this episode Andrew MacKenzie opens the program with the paintings of artist Tony Clark on exhibition at Anna Schwartz gallery. Clark’s work explores the representation of landscape within a historical and cultural context articulating the ritualisation of cultural motifs. Anna Schwartz talks openly with MacKenzie about her curatorial philosophy and gallery practise. Level 11 Gallery, shows the drawings of Asa Letourneau. At Cube 37, Frankston Arts Centre, ‘Eternity’, celebrates the cultural diversity of the graffiti artist as a matured aesthetic and practice. At Bus, Phil Edwards looks at redundant culture in “Not Building”. Natascha Frisch and Kate Cotching collaborate using the paper medium to describe place and time. Screen Talk visits the Wednesday night screening at Croft Institute and shows the video of Mandy Morgan, ‘Placelike’.

results.title: Australian women's heritage: 1901-1945
results.brief_description: This visual history of Australian women documents the contribution of an often overlooked group. Their work, their mothering and their civilising influence has been a major factor in Australia’s coming of age. Yet women have been receiving second class status from officialdom since the earliest days of Australia’s settlement. This program begins by looking at the reduction in the size of families, the White Australia policy and changes in society’s views on morality. It looks at both World Wars and their impact on Australian women. The contrast between the flappers and the poverty of the 1920’s is interesting to consider. Jewish refugees and British immigrants, votes for women, changes in fashion and issues important to Aboriginal women are all discussed. Individual women highlighted in this episode include Vida Goldstein, Muriel Heagney, Elizabeth Kenny, Dame Enid Lyons, Dame Mary Gilmore and Katherine Suzannah Pritchard.

results.title: Manyu-Wana 5
results.creator_credit: David Batty, Wendy Baarda and Warlpiri Media
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Manyu-Wana (A)”.
This episode covers the following topics: Holly magic; words for ‘happy’ and ‘serious’; reading of a “Story about Echidnas”’ number 8; story about a bush potato dreaming place; more on numbers, using doll magic; dreaming stories about places southwest of Yuendumu; boys and girls painted up and doing fire-dreaming dances; good food; bush animals, vegetables, fruits and seeds; working at the shop; bike magic. Suitable for Primary, Secondary and Tertiary level students. In Warlpiri language with English subtitles.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Batty, Wendy Baarda and Warlpiri Media

results.title: Manyu-Wana 2
results.creator_credit: David Batty, Wendy Baarda and Warlpiri Media
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Manyu-Wana (A)”.
This episode covers the following topics: Working for the Yuendumu Mining Co.; reading of “The Story of the Perentie”; words for ‘far’ and ‘close’; cleaning teeth, washing eyes; fire-making; story about a little kangaroo looking for its mother; shirt magic; number 2. Suitable for Primary, Secondary and Tertiary level students. In Warlpiri language with English subtitles.

results.title: Manyu-Wana 3
results.creator_credit: David Batty, Wendy Baarda and Warlpiri Media
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Manyu-Wana (A)”.
This episode covers the following topics: Children playing; dampers magic-number 6; exercising for health, showing football and basketball matches between communitites; spear-throwing at Yuendumu Sports; reading of “The Story about the Snake and the Mouse”; words for ‘heavy’ and ‘light’; colours; cleaning and grinding of bush seeds for seed cakes. Suitable for Primary, seconday and Tertiary level students. In Warlpiri language with Englsih subtitles.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Batty, Wendy Baarda and Warlpiri Media
results.description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Manyu-Wana (A)”.
This episode covers the following topics: Children playing; dampers magic-number 6; exercising for health, showing football and basketball matches between communitites; spear-throwing at Yuendumu Sports; reading of “The Story about the Snake and the Mouse”; words for ‘heavy’ and ‘light’; colours; cleaning and grinding of bush seeds for seed cakes. Suitable for Primary, seconday and Tertiary level students. In Warlpiri language with Englsih subtitles.

results.title: Banduk
results.creator_credit: Di Drew, Penelope Spence and National Nine Network
results.brief_description: Banduk, a young Aboriginal girl, and her friends discover that the “friendly” proprietors of an ice-cream van are smuggling native animals, including the sacred red-collared parakeet, out of Australia. This delightful story was filmed on location in Arnhem Land.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Di Drew, Penelope Spence and National Nine Network
